title: File previews
content:
Overview

File previews covers stream-friendly previews and lightweight inspection. This advanced section assumes you already know the basics and want faster, safer workflows.

Prerequisites

Make sure you are comfortable with basic navigation, listing, and reading manual pages before applying these techniques.

Why it matters

Advanced users save time by reducing ambiguity and verifying results quickly. These patterns help you avoid subtle mistakes.

Example: baseline command

Start from a reliable baseline and expand from there.

❯ head -n 10 /etc/passwd
first line

Confirm you understand every flag before stacking more.

Example: inspection

Inspect system state before you change anything.

❯ tail -n 5 /var/log/system.log 2>/dev/null
last line

Write down what you expect the output to show.

Example: controlled execution

Use controlled execution to reduce side effects.

❯ less /etc/services
sample output

Prefer dry runs or read-only checks when available.

Example: repeatability

Make the command easy to repeat or script.

❯ wc -l /etc/passwd
10 file.txt

Keep commands small and composable.

Example: verification step

Always verify the change after running a command.

❯ sed -n "1,5p" /etc/group
sample output

Verification is what makes advanced workflows safe.

Performance notes

Use targeted queries and narrow filters. Broad scans can be slow or noisy on large systems.

Safety checklist

Double-check paths, confirm targets, and avoid running destructive commands without backups.

Troubleshooting

If output is unexpected, simplify the command and add flags one by one to isolate the issue.

Practice tasks

Apply the examples in a practice folder, then explain the output in your own words.

Recap

You now have advanced patterns for File previews. Use them consistently to build speed and accuracy.
